Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Sam: “Rough day. Can you talk?” I glanced at the clock—6:15 p.m.—and then at the error logs on my screen. The build was stuck, and everyone was waiting on my module. My inbox was filling with “Any update?” emails from the team. I knew they couldn’t move forward until I fixed this, but Sam rarely reached out like this. As a friend, I wanted to be there, to listen and help him unwind after his awful day. But as the lead engineer, I was expected to solve this problem, fast. My mind raced, torn between opening a call with Sam and diving deeper into the code. I could almost hear the disappointment in both directions—Sam’s if I ignored him, my team’s if I delayed. My chest tightened as I stared at the phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which to choose.
